meanings.definition: To reverse the creation of something.
meanings.sent1: She wanted to unmake the paper airplane and start over.
meanings.sent2: The wizard could unmake his spells with a simple gesture.
meanings.sent3: Trying to unmake a cake after baking it is like trying to unscramble an egg.
meanings.sent4: The artist's brush seemed to unmake the colors on the canvas, leaving only a blank space.
meanings.sent5: The time machine allowed him to unmake his mistakes and rewrite history.

meanings.definition: To destroy or undo something that has been made.
meanings.sent1: The villain's plan was to unmake the hero's efforts and bring chaos.
meanings.sent2: The eraser can unmake any pencil marks on the paper.
meanings.sent3: He tried to unmake the sandcastle, but the waves beat him to it.
meanings.sent4: The fire's heat seemed to unmake the ice sculpture, turning it into a puddle.
meanings.sent5: The potion had the power to unmake any enchantments placed on the castle.

meanings.definition: To cause something to cease to exist.
meanings.sent1: The loud noise seemed to unmake the peaceful atmosphere of the park.
meanings.sent2: The decision to cut funding could unmake the progress of the project.
meanings.sent3: His apology could not unmake the hurtful words he had said.
meanings.sent4: The storm threatened to unmake the fragile sandcastle on the beach.
meanings.sent5: The virus had the ability to unmake all the data stored on the computer.
